structured_content.content: This cozy shrimp dish is the perfect antidote to chilly nights, combining the sweetness of shrimp with a touch of olive oil for a simple yet satisfying meal. The aroma of cooking shrimp will fill your kitchen, inviting everyone to the table.

structured_content.content: I remember the first time I made this dish for my family; the smiles on their faces as they took the first bite made it a cherished memory. It's a recipe that brings us together, especially on those cold winter evenings.

• Main ingredient: Fresh shrimp are best for this dish; look for ones that are firm and have a mild ocean scent.
  • Key seasonings/flavoring agents: Olive oil adds richness and helps in browning the shrimp.

structured_content.content:
Preparation:
Start by peeling and deveining the shrimp if not already done. Pat them dry to ensure a good sear.
Cooking/Baking Process:
Heat the olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Once hot, add the shrimp in a single layer. Cook for 2-3 minutes on each side until they turn pink and opaque.
Finishing Touches:
Serve immediately with a sprinkle of fresh herbs or a squeeze of lemon for brightness.

note.label: You Must Know
note.content:
• Cook shrimp just until they are opaque; overcooking will make them rubbery.
  • A common mistake is overcrowding the pan, which can lead to steaming instead of searing.
  • They are ready when they turn pink and curl slightly.
  • Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 2 days.

Add a pinch of red pepper flakes for heat, or toss in some fresh herbs like parsley or cilantro for a burst of freshness. A dash of soy sauce can also enhance the umami flavor.
Pair this dish with a light salad, crusty bread, or over a bed of rice or pasta. A crisp white wine or sparkling water with lemon makes for a refreshing accompaniment.
For a gluten-free option, serve the shrimp over quinoa or cauliflower rice. You can also substitute shrimp with chicken or tofu for different dietary preferences.

note.label: Pro Tips
note.content:
• For restaurant-quality results, let the shrimp sit at room temperature for 15 minutes before cooking.
  • Marinate the shrimp in olive oil, garlic, and herbs for maximum flavor.
  • Keep an eye on the cooking time to avoid overcooking.
  • Garnish with fresh herbs for an impressive presentation.
